en.sc1: Consider inserting a record with key value 30 in this tree. We call the helper method with a Node object to the BST root (the node with value 37).
en.sc2: Check what node is pointing to. It is not None.
en.sc3: Check the value at the node. We find that it is greater than what we are looking for.
en.sc4: So we want to visit the left child.
en.sc5: We make a recursive call with the left child as the new node.
en.sc7: Check the value at the node. We find that it is less than what we are looking for.
en.sc8: So we want to visit the right child.
en.sc9: We make a recursive call with the right child as the new node.
en.sc14: Check what node is pointing to. This time it is None! So make a new node.
en.sc15: At this point we have hit the base case on the recursive process. So now we will return out of the current instance of the method.
en.sc16: Unwinding the recursion one level brings us the node with value 32, which is to the parent of the new node that we just created. We now re-assign its left pointer to point to the return value from the call to inserthelp (the new node that we had just created).
en.sc17: Unwinding the recursion another level brings us the node with value 24. We now re-assign its right node to point to the return value from the call to the method.
en.sc18: Unwinding the recursion another level brings us the node with value 37. We now re-assign its right node to point to the return value from the call to the method.
en.sc19: Finally we return from initial call to helper method, returning a pointer to the node with value 37 (the root of the original tree). We now re-assign the BST's root node.
